data.text: Index
Introduction
Scope
Definitions
Roles and Responsibilities

References
Equality Impact Assessment
Appendices
Appendix 1: Types of Abuse & Possible Indicators Appendix 2: Safeguarding Best Practice Matrix Appendix 3: Safeguarding Checklist
Appendix 4: Preliminary Equality Assessment
Introduction

This policy sets out the safeguarding responsibilities of all staff including paid, voluntary and contracted staff, in the recognition and prevention of adult abuse, and the actions to take when abuse is suspected or identified, in compliance with responsibilities set out in the Care Act April (2014). It is the responsibility of all staff to ensure the safety and protection of adults at risk of abuse, to treat the abuse or potential abuse of adults seriously and to act on any suspicion or evidence of abuse.

The Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) recognises that reporting abuse may be difficult for staff and is committed to supporting staff in undertaking their safeguarding duties. The Chief Nurse, Site Directors of Nursing, Associate and Deputy Associate Director for Safeguarding Services, Adult Safeguarding Lead, Adult Safeguarding Advisors, Heads of Nursing, Senior Managers and direct Line Managers, will all act as sources of support.

This Policy is supplementary to The Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Safeguarding Adults Guideline, Version 5 (April 2019) to provides an overview of the local arrangements to comply with these guidelines.
All service users are entitled access to the safeguarding adult services regardless of:
Age;
Disability;
Gender reassignment;
Marriage and civil partnership;
Pregnancy and maternity;
Race;
Religion and belief;
Sex;
Sexual Orientation.
In May 2011 the Department of Health issued a statement on Safeguarding Adults which sets out six safeguarding principles which should underpin all safeguarding work.
Empowerment – Presumption of person led decisions and informed consent.
Protection – Support and representation for those in greatest need.
Prevention – It is better to take action before harm occurs.
Proportionality – Proportional and least restrictive response appropriate to the risk presented.
Partnership – Local solutions through services working with their communities. Communities have a part to play in preventing, detecting and reporting neglect and abuse.
Accountability – Accountability and transparency in delivering safeguarding
The Trust is committed to upholding and following these safeguarding principles.
Scope

This policy is aimed at all staff working within Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) who come into contact with adults over  years that come into contact with our services that are at risk of abuse. Include 16 year and  year of age in cases of domestic abuse and the Mental Capacity Act 2005.

The MSE Safeguarding Group promote a Think Family Approach to safeguarding and expect all staff to consider the safety and wellbeing of all connected individuals when abuse is recognised or suspected. This may require reference to the Childrens Safeguarding Policy if required.
Definitions
This policy covers the main categories of abuse:

table_items.text: Hitting, slapping, pushing, kicking, misuse of medication, misuse of restraints, inappropriate sanctions.

The definition of domestic abuse used by the Home Office and most agencies is: Any incident or pattern of incidents of controlling, coercive, threatening behaviour, violence or abuse between those aged 16 or over who are, or have been, intimate partners or family members regardless of gender or sexuality. The abuse can encompass, but is not limited to: psychological physical sexual financial emotional See Policy for the management of victims of domestic abuse.

Includes procedures that intentionally alter or cause injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons. The procedure has no health benefits for girls and women. WHO http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs241/en/

The Home Office definition of forced marriage is: 'A marriage without the consent of one or both parties and where duress is a factor'. The Court of Appeal clarified that duress is: '[when] the mind of the applicant has been overborne, howsoever that was caused'. An arranged marriage is very different from a forced marriage. An arranged marriage is entered into freely by both people, although their families take a leading role in the choice of partner. A forced marriage is where one or both people do not (or in some cases of people with learning or physical disabilities, cannot) consent to the marriage and pressure, coercion or abuse is used. Forced marriages can occur in this country or abroad, often in their country of origin. For further information on Forced Marriage follow the link: https://www.gov.uk/forced-marriage.

Forced Marriage Unit at the Home Office defines honour based violence in the following way: "So-called honour based violence is a crime or incident, which has or may have been committed to protect or defend the honour of the family and/or community”
Rape and sexual assault, or sexual acts to which the adult has not consented, or could not consent or where pressure was applied to secure their consent.
Verbal abuse, psychological abuse, threats, humiliation, blaming, controlling, intimidation, coercion, harassment, isolation or withdrawal from services.

Institutional abuse occurs where the culture of the organisation, such as a hospital, places emphasis on the running of the establishment and the needs of the staff above the needs and care of the person at risk of abuse. Abuse by an organisation imposing rigid and insensitive routines can lead to failure to ensure the necessary safeguards are in place to protect adults at risk of abuse and maintain good standards of care in accordance with individual needs, including training of staff, supervision and management, record keeping and liaising with other providers of care.
Theft, fraud, exploitation, pressure in connection with wills, property or inheritance or financial transactions, or the misuse or misappropriation of property or possession or benefits.

Ignoring medical or physical care needs, failure to provide access to appropriate Health, Social Care or Educational Services. The withholding of the necessities of life, such as medication, food and drink, preventable pressure damage and failed discharge may be considered as acts of neglect.
This covers a wide range of behaviours where individuals neglect to attend to their basic needs, such as personal hygiene, health or surroundings.

Modern slavery – encompasses slavery, human trafficking, forced labour and domestic servitude. Traffickers and slave masters use whatever means they have at their disposal to coerce, deceive and force individuals into a life of abuse, servitude and inhumane treatment. Possible indicators include Poor physical appearance, isolation, poor living conditions, few or no personal effects, restricted freedom of movement, unusual travel habits, reluctance to seek help For more information see the Modern Day Slavery Act http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2015/30/contents/enacted/data.htm:

Prevent is one of the four strands of a cross government, counter terrorism strategy called CONTEST which aims to stop people from becoming terrorists (often referred to as being radicalised) or supporting terrorism. The Department of Health and the Home Office have developed guidance for healthcare organisations, to enable them to implement Prevent locally, called “Building Partnerships, staying Safe”. See policy for ‘Safeguarding vulnerable people who may be at risk of being drawn into terrorism'
Includes forms of harassment, slurs or similar treatments; because of race, gender and gender identity, age, disability, sexual orientation or religion.

data.text: Definitions within this policy

table_items.text: The Care Act 2014 does not set out a specific definition of abuse other than to state that it includes financial abuse which includes: (a). having money or other property stolen, (b). being defrauded, (c). being put under pressure in relation to money or other property, (d). having money or other property misused. The Act's statutory guidance lists ten types of abuse but states that local authorities should not limit their view of what constitutes abuse or neglect to those types or the different circumstances in which they can take place. It is therefore, also important to recognise that abuse can consist of a single or repeated act(s); that it can be intentional or unintentional or result from a lack of knowledge. Abuse can be an act of neglect or an omission or a failure to act. Abuse can cause temporary harm or exist over a period of time and can occur in any relationship. Abuse can be perpetrated by anyone, individually or as part of a group or organisation. Importantly, abuse can often constitute a crime.
Coercive behaviour is an act or a pattern of acts of assault, threats, humiliation and intimidation or other abuse that is used to harm, punish, or frighten their victim.

Controlling behaviour is a range of acts designed to make a person subordinate and/or dependent by isolating them from sources of support, exploiting their resources and capacities for personal gain, depriving them of the means needed for independence, resistance and escape and regulating their everyday behaviour.

Multi Agency Risk Assessment Conference The main aim of the MARAC is to reduce the risk of serious harm or homicide for a domestic abuse victim and to increase the safety, health and wellbeing of other victims, both adults and any children. In a MARAC local agencies will meet to discuss the highest risk victims of domestic abuse in their area. Information about the risks faced by those victims, the actions needed to ensure safety, and the resources available locally are shared and used to create a risk management plan involving all agencies.

If you have mental capacity, you can make decisions for yourself. The legal definition says someone who lacks capacity cannot do one or more of the following four things: Understand information given to them

Retain that information long enough to be able to make a decision Weigh up the information available to make a decision Communicate their decision. Office of the Public Guardian 2007 For more information see Policy for Mental Capacity Act 2005 Any assessment of mental capacity must be decision and time specific.
Southend, Essex and Thurrock Safeguarding Adults Form

“ill treatment (including sexual abuse and forms of ill treatment that are not physical); the impairment of, or an avoidable deterioration in, physical or mental health, and the impairment of physical , emotional, social or behavioural development” (“Who Decides” Lord Chancellor's Department 1997)
Safeguarding Of Vulnerable Adults – referred to as adults at risk of abuse

The purpose of adult safeguarding is to prevent harm and reduce the risk of abuse or neglect to adults with care and support needs. The statutory framework introduced under the Care Act applies to any person aged 18 or above who: Has needs for care and support (regardless of the level of need and whether or not the local authority is meeting any of those needs) Is experiencing, or is at risk of abuse or neglect, and As a result of those needs, is unable to protect themselves against the abuse or neglect or the risk of it.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
MSE Chief Nurse
The Chief Nurse, as Executive Lead for Safeguarding, is responsible for ensuring that the Trust Board / Executive is aware of, and discharges its statutory safeguarding duties.
Clinical Directors Responsible for
Ensuring that policies and procedures are communicated and implemented across the Directorates/Corporate Function.
Incorporate relevant aspects of the Policy into local induction arrangements
Nominate a representative to sit on the MSE Safeguarding Committee in Common
Implement and support the monitoring of action plans generated to support the work of the Safeguarding Adults agenda.
Ensure that staff involved in safeguarding adults at risk have access to appropriate training, advice and support.
Ensure that named professionals will in conjunction with Occupational Health provide appropriate advice and support to staff exposed to sensitive and distressing situations.
The Trust Board / Executive

The Board has overall responsibility for ensuring the MSE Group makes an effective contribution towards inter-agency working with partner agencies and for appropriately prioritising safeguarding adults at risk in its allocation of resources for service and professional training and development. This includes representation at Safeguarding Adult Board Meetings / Partnerships and Subgroups.

4.3.1  The Board has nominated the Chief Nurse and Director of Nursing to be responsible for assuring the safety and welfare of adults at risk, and for updating the relevant policies and ensuring that the necessary procedures are available for all staff.
Director of Nursing (With MSE Responsibility for Safeguarding)
Responsible for ensuring the implementation and delivery of policies and procedures to safeguard adults at risk including:
Oversight of safeguarding practice within the MSE structure.
Appointing an Associate and Deputy Associate Director for Safeguarding Services across the MSE Group
Monitoring the effectiveness of the Safeguarding Adults process and provide assurance to the Board, via the Chief Nurse, that the Trust is meeting its safeguarding statutory duty
Associate Director for Safeguarding Service (Group Role) Responsible for:

The development and leadership of a robust culture of safeguarding practice across the MSE group, providing strategic and corporate direction including complex professional advice on matters relating to safeguarding individuals at risk:

To lead the organisation on collaborative working practices across both agency and geographical boundaries, with providers of health and social care and other partner agencies, to provide a seamless approach to safeguarding individuals at risk. An approach that incorporates a holistic family approach to any individual at risk of or being abused
To promote the early accurate identification and management of safeguarding concerns by professional leadership, expert practice, research and education
Ensuring that national and local recommendations from emergent safeguarding work are implemented across the Trust and are included within its policies and practice

Leading a robust culture of safeguarding, directed through the approved MSB safeguarding governance reporting structure, including the Safeguarding Operational Groups, Learning Disabilities Operational Group, Children and Adults Safeguarding Committee in Common and the Quality Committee in Common
Provide expert advice to staff across the MSE group on all matters of safeguarding adults and children
Demonstrate advanced skills and competencies to influence the pathways of care in safeguarding children and young people and adults at risk
Initiate and add to research evidence in the field of safeguarding to ensure that evidence-based practice is inherent in all aspects of care
Ensure a Safeguarding Audit Programme is in place to facilitate learning
Named Nurse for Safeguarding Adults (Group Role)
Responsible for:
Ensuring training is consistent with local and national guidelines
Ensuring that safeguarding referrals submitted meet the thresholds identified in The Care Act.
Responding effectively to any concerns raised regarding safeguarding by any member of staff. Provides advice consistent with national and local expectations.
Ensuring effective databases are maintained.
Attending necessary local safeguarding forums (including any forums that come under the remit of safeguarding) and disseminate information accordingly.
Ensuring relevant information is disseminated
Named Doctor for Safeguarding Adults Responsible for:
Championing safeguarding within the Organisation and provide expert medical advice
Providing specialist advice and co-ordination
Working alongside the Safeguarding Team and contribute to compliance to the Trusts Safeguarding Duty
Attending necessary local safeguarding forums, and disseminate information accordingly
Ensuring relevant information is disseminated
Assisting in the promotion of training compliance for medical staff
Adult Safeguarding Advisors (Site role)
The Adult Safeguarding Advisors has delegated responsibility to:
Provide support and training to staff in the implementation of the Safeguarding Adults Policy
Alert risk management via the Datix system when allegations of abuse are made against the Trust.
Contribute towards the setting, monitoring and maintenance of robust safeguarding arrangements and training programmes.
Contribute to collaborative interagency working and quality assurance frameworks for safeguarding by ensuring representation at Safeguarding Adults Boards / partnerships and subgroups.
Provide expert clinical leadership and direction for service users and staff

Take responsibility for actions to meet health and social care needs of adults at risk.. This includes working across organisations and in partnership at both strategic and operational level, leading the safeguarding initiatives across the health economy, and working closely with other safeguarding leads.
Directors of Nursing, Heads of Nursing, Matrons, Ward Sisters/ Charge Nurses, Allied Health Professionals, Team Leaders and all Health Professionals
Responsible for:

The implementation of the Safeguarding Adults policy across their divisions and facilitate/support the Adult Safeguarding Specialist, ensuring staff receive the appropriate training to enable them to work within the principles of this policy.
Ensuring their staff in their divisions are compliant with training.
All Staff

All staff have a responsibility, regardless of grade or position, to take action if they become aware of Safeguarding concerns. This will include a duty to report actual or suspected abuse to their Line Manager; and the completion and submission of a Datix Incident Reporting form and a SET SAF form where appropriate, notifying the Adult Safeguarding Specialist within usual working hours or the Clinical Operations Managers out of hours. All safeguarding issues should be addressed as a matter of urgency, and any necessary SETSAF's will be required to be submitted within 24 hours.
Completing relevant mandatory training in relation to Adult Safeguarding according to their role.
Ensuring they know how to recognise signs of abuse and taking appropriate actions to prevent this.
Ensuring they are aware of Trust processes for reporting abuse (including suspected) and the location of appropriate safeguarding referral forms.
Being aware that ‘If it is determined that a person lacks capacity then any decision taken on their behalf must be in their best interest (MCA 2005).
Role and Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
Operational Adult and Child Safeguarding Committees oversee all Operational safeguarding children activity including training compliance and adherence to policies.

MSE Group Adult and Child Safeguarding Committee oversees assurance to the Trust Board that policies, systems and procedures and in place, disseminated and adhered to, to safeguard children, young people and adults at risk. Provides assurance on the implementation, monitoring and updating of policies, systems, and procedures within the Trust for safeguarding children, young people, and adults at risk. Responding to changes in local and national guidance, legislation, and best practice.
4.11.1 Divisional Leads and Ward Sister's/Managers are responsible for ensuring staff access training in line with all other mandatory training requirements.
Safeguarding Process
Reporting a safeguarding concern

Any member of staff (Voluntary, paid or contracted) working within the MSE Trust who become aware of an allegation of abuse, suspects abuse or recognises actual abuse against an adult at risk occurring within or outside the Trust must take the following actions:

Raise an alert internally: Immediately raise concerns with the person in charge, their line manager or out of hours, the Site Team, and establish whether any further information is required. Documentation of facts-not opinion-is essential. Allegations of adult abuse must always be referred to the Site Safeguarding Teams at the earliest point. Within normal working hours (Monday – Friday, 9am – 5pm), directly contact the Adult Safeguarding Team via pager or telephone to escalate all potential safeguarding concerns/referrals to support decision making /advice. If urgent safeguarding advice is required out of hours then the Site Manager can make a decision as to whether the concern warrants consultation with a Duty Social Worker. (Contact numbers can be found on the SET SAF form.
Take immediate action to safeguard the individual: Ensure the alleged victim receives medical attention if required and reassurance in a sensitive way.

Consider a place of safety: Ensure the victim is placed or remains in an appropriate safe environment. The safety of an individual at risk must be considered and assured before discharge. This may require an urgent review with social care (or Domestic Abuse Service Provider where there are cases of domestic abuse) to consider an appropriate protection plan / place of safety. To assist with the protection plan, when referring, provide as much information as possible, including signs and symptoms of abuse. Consider:
Physical indicators;
Behavioural indicators;
Emotional changes;
Disclosure (Ask and listen).
Ask the patient:
What has happened?
Assess for injuries
Explain what your concerns are and what a safeguarding referral means
Discuss immediate actions to maintain the individual safety
Consider others who may be at risk
Ask the individual what outcome they would like / what would help to make them feel safe. Remember to “Make Safeguarding Personal”
Ensure all discussions are documented within the individual's records and use appropriate tools such as body maps, where required.

Involve the adult at risk: The Care Act requires staff to make the safeguarding process personal to the patient / individual. Views of the alleged victim should be established and reflected within a completed SETSAF safeguarding referral form. Staff should also include what the patient / individuals preferred outcomes are and ensure that they are aware of the contents of the SETSAF, and the next steps. Wherever possible, allow the patient to read the SETSAF, and then sign as having read it, before sending. All parts of the SETSAF must be completed fully. Seek advice if required.

Safeguarding allegations against the Trust or a member of the Trust: In the event of a referral against the Trust being required an incident form must be completed and a SET SAF form will need to be completed by the staff member who highlighted the concern or was notified of the concern. A copy of the completed SET SAF form must always be emailed to the MSE site specific safeguarding email addresses (internal) and securely to the relevant local authority if possible using the addresses below.

table_items.text: Making a referral/enquiry by telephone: 01702 215008 (option 1) Out of hours referrals: General public - 0345 606 1212 Statutory agencies – 0300 123 0778
0345 603 7630 Out of hours referrals: General public - 0345 606 1212 Statutory agencies – 0300 123 0778
Making a referral/enquiry by telephone: 01375 511000 Out of hours referrals: Phone: 01375 372468 Fax: 01375 397080)

data.text: MSE Local Safeguarding Team Contacts (Internal):
Southend Hospital: Telephone: 01702 435555 Ext 7239, 6881 or 8734 Mobile: 07769671349
Safeguarding.Adults@southend.nhs.uk
Safeguarding.adults@nhs.net
Basildon Hospital :
Mid Essex Hospital:
Phone: 01245 516943. Internal 6943.
E mail: sat@meht.nhs.uk
Out of hours Advice
5.9.1 Where possible, the original SET SAF must be kept in the patient's medical notes and details recorded in the medical notes, unless advised otherwise by the Adult Safeguarding Team.
5.9.2 To support staff to ascertain whether a concern may require a SET SAF form and meet the threshold for a referral please refer to the Safeguarding Adults Best Practice Matrix, Appendix

5.9.3 For any safeguarding adult concerns raised by members of the public which may relate for example to a friend/neighbour/carer outside please refer them to the relevant Social Care team / Local Authority.

5.9.3  Out of hours, the Site Team should be consulted to establish whether any further information is required to report any safeguarding concerns if it is believed that an adult is at risk. Allegations of adult abuse must always be referred to the Site Safeguarding Teams at the earliest point. If urgent safeguarding advice is required out of hours, then the Site Manager can make a decision as to whether the concern

warrants consultation with a Duty Social Worker. (Contact numbers can be found on the SET SAF form). Relevant Head of Nursing should be informed as soon as possible with details of the allegation and actions taken.
Safeguarding and Whistleblowing

If for any reason a member of staff cannot undertake these responsibilities, the Trust policy, Speaking Up – How to Raise a Concern Policy (formerly Whistleblowing Policy) provides an alternative route to raise concerns. But all staff should be reminded of their duty under safeguarding process and alternative routes of escalation / reporting should only be considered in exceptional circumstances.
Safeguarding and Police Involvement

5.11.1 If it is believed that a crime may have occurred, then reporting an incident to the police must be considered with a Senior Manager or the Safeguarding Team. A Senor Manager or a Safeguarding Adults Lead must contact the police if a criminal offence has been committed or is suspected. This must also be escalated as soon as possible to the Director of Nursing. If required, out of hours, the Site Manager will escalate to the Senior Manager on call.

5.11.2 Where criminal activity is suspected, immediate referral or consultation with the Police will enable the Police to establish whether a crime has been committed and this will give an opportunity of determining the need for further criminal investigation. The Police have powers to initiate specific protective actions which may apply. Early contact with the Police may assist in obtaining and securing evidence and witness statements, as well as ensuring that forensic evidence is not lost or contaminated.

5.11.3 In circumstances where a criminal offence has occurred i.e. suspected or actual sexual or physical abuse or an incident of domestic abuse where there is a perceived risk, the Police should be contacted as a matter of urgency in order to secure forensic evidence (i.e. contact Police before anyone else/before completing a SETSAF).

5.11.4 In circumstances where a criminal offence has occurred where there is a perceived risk to the individual or others, the Police may need to be informed as a matter of urgency, even if the patient does not want the Police contacted. If in any doubt, escalate this to the Adult Safeguarding Team in working hours, or a Site Manager when out of hours.

5.11.5 In circumstances where sexual abuse is disclosed or suspected, the Police must be contacted urgently and a referral to SARC (Sexual Assault Referral Centre), on 01277 240620 should be considered.
Safeguarding and Domestic abuse
In circumstances where domestic abuse is disclosed or suspected contact the domestic abuse support service COMPASS:
Essex Domestic Abuse Helpline: 0330 333 7 444
On the Mid Essex and Southend sites, COMPASS continue to provide support, advice and access to refuges as indicated.
https://www.essexcompass.org.uk/
On the Basildon site, the Essex Domestic Abuse Partnership Project (EDAPP) are on site 9am to 5pm Monday to Friday.
Outside of these hours COMPASS should be contacted.
5.12.1 Staff should refer to Trust Domestic Abuse Policies for further guidance including when a referral to MARAC (Multi Agency Risk Assessment) may be required.
Power of attorney

If staff have concerns about the actions of an attorney acting under a registered Enduring Power of Attorney (EPA) or Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA), or a Deputy appointed by the Court of Protection, they should contact the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG). The OPG can investigate the actions of a Deputy or Attorney and can also refer concerns to other relevant agencies.
5.13.1 Any claim by an individual to be a LPA or EPA should be challenged and the relevant paperwork from the OPG should be supplied.
Mental Capacity

Where possible, the individual should be encouraged to make their own decisions in the context of their own lives. Staff must refer to the Trust / MSE Mental Capacity Policy if there is a suggestion that the individual lacks capacity in decision related to the safeguarding concern. If an adult at risk lacks capacity then actions should be taken in the best interest of the individual (refer to MCA and best interest policy)
Immediate Actions for the Nurse in Charge following first Reporting of Abuse Ensure that a member of staff reassures the alleged victim(s).
Believe what the victim is saying and ensure the recording of any disclosures in their own words.
Seek medical attention for the victim as required with sensitivity to the gender of the doctor where there is a possibility of sexual abuse.
Maintain the safety of the alleged victim, preserve any evidence, ensuring they remain in hospital or are discharged to an appropriate and safe environment.

Arrange medical photography of any obvious physical injuries including pressure damage and bruising. If the patient does not have capacity to consent to this, then a mental Capacity Assessment and best interests decision would be required.
Provide support as required to any member of staff completing a SET SAF.

The nurse in charge must undertake a risk assessment to establish whether the alleged perpetrator continues to present a risk to the patient concerned. If an on-going risk is identified appropriate contact restrictions such as restricted visiting may need to be enforced and discussed with the Local Security Management Specialist and Senior Managers.
If the alleged abuser is a member of staff, then this concern must be reported immediately to their line manager, who will contact and discuss with a Senior

Manager / Head of Nursing within that Directorate / Division. Out of hours. The on-call Duty Manager should be informed via the Site Team. A Senior Manager and Human Resource Department will then consider action under the disciplinary procedure.
The alleged abuser should receive minimal necessary information regarding the allegation until the Adult Safeguarding Team, or the Police if they are involved, have agreed a course of action.
Report the incident via the site incident reporting system in accordance with the Incident Policy and complete a SET SAF Safeguarding referral.
Action following Completion of SET SAF

The Adult Social Care Team are responsible for co-ordinating investigations / Section 42 Enquiries into allegations of abuse on receipt of a SET SAF form. The Mid & South Essex University Hospitals Trust (MSE) has a statutory duty to investigate and respond to any Section  Enquiry raised by the Local Authority
5.16.1 The nurse in charge must:
Ensure details of the alleged abuse are communicated verbally when the patient is transferred between wards and departments
Liaise with, and assist the investigating officer
Arrange visits from Doctor, Police and Investigating Officer as required

Ensure necessary agencies and the next of kin are effectively communicated with, and consider if a referral to the Independent Mental Capacity Advocate is required (refer to Mental Capacity Act Policy)
Consider the implications for safe discharge and document these (for instance, if the alleged perpetrator will continue to put the individual at risk after discharge)
All SET SAF referral against the Trust must be reported as an incident via the
site Incident Reporting System.
Allegations against the MSE Group or any site / service within it

5.17.1 When a SET SAF is received from Adult Social Care against any of the sites within the MSE Group, the following actions must be taken by the Investigating officer / staff member assigned to respond to the enquiry on behalf of the relevant division / directorate.

5.17.2 An attempt must be made to discuss with the patient, contact the next of kin as outlined on the SET SAF form, unless there would be a known risk of doing so. An apology should be provided and an explanation of the safeguarding processes.

5.17.3 Consider contact with other services such as the Complaints Team, to ensure there is no duplication of process. If an incident is covered within more than just the Safeguarding Process, then a combined response should be considered where possible.

5.17.4 It is the responsibility of the Service Manager to ensure completion of the safeguarding investigation / Section  Enquiry and respond within the timescale identified by the Adult Safeguarding Team. The Adult Safeguarding Team will be available to provide advice and support with any investigations.

5.17.5 The completed SET SAF response investigations will be reviewed by the Safeguarding Adult Lead and Adult Safeguarding Advisors. Once reviewed the investigations are sent for approval and sign off from the site-specific Director of Nursing with all relevant staff copied into the request or agreed though the site Director Review Group. Following approval, the Site Adult Safeguarding Team will submit the report securely to the Local Authority.

5.17.6 It is expected that Service Managers / Head of Nursing will discuss the learning that has taken place at local / ward-based meeting and take on the responsibility for the completion and evidencing of any recommendations or actions required.
Confidentiality

5.18.1 People have a right to expect that their contact with, and any information they give to statutory agencies, will be treated confidentially unless disclosure is justified (refer to Trust's Sharing Patient Information Policy and the site Caldicott Guardian for guidance). The Trust has agreed to the Information Sharing Protocol with the Essex Safeguarding Adult Board and has a duty to share information appropriately with necessary agencies in line with The Care Act  Information Sharing must be consistent with General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (2018).
5.18.2 There are occasions when it will be necessary to share information with other agencies even without the permission of the alleged victim and these are as follows:
If a criminal offence has occurred or is suspected;
If there is a significantly high risk to the individual;
If there are risks to children i.e. <18 years old;
If there are risks to other adults;
If the alleged perpetrator is a member of staff/volunteer consideration for referring to Local Authority Designated Officer (LADO).

5.18.3 The Trust is a signatory to the Essex Charter on Data Sharing as are all the acute Trusts and public bodies working in health related fields and whilst appropriate information must be shared to protect the individual, this must be done using secure and acceptable media. – Consult with Information Governance.
Information Sharing

5.19.1 Early information sharing is required to ensure effective safeguarding of adults. The wellbeing and safety of adults at risk of abuse is likely to be more important than concerns about sharing information.
5.19.2 Staff should only share as much information as they need to achieve the purpose for which the information is being shared.

5.19.3 If there are concerns about an adult's welfare and there is the belief that they are suffering abuse of neglect, these concerns should be shared with the local authority in line with the SET Safeguarding process.
5.19.4 The 7 Golden rules for information sharing
i). Remember that the Data Protection Act is not a barrier to sharing information but provides a framework to ensure that personal information about living persons is shared appropriately.

ii). Be open and honest with the person (and/or their family where appropriate) from the outset about why, what, how and with whom information will, or could be shared, and seek their agreement, unless it is unsafe or inappropriate to do so.
iii). Seek advice if you are in any doubt, without disclosing the identity of the person where possible.

iv). Share with consent where appropriate and, where possible, respect the wishes of those who do not consent to share confidential information. You may still share information without consent if, in your judgement, that lack of consent can be overridden in the public interest. You will need to base your judgement on the facts of the case.
v). Consider safety and well-being: Base your information sharing decisions on considerations of the safety and well-being of the person and others who may be affected by their actions.

vi). Necessary, proportionate, relevant, accurate, timely and secure: Ensure that the information you share is necessary for the purpose for which you are sharing it, is shared only with those people who need to have it, is accurate and up- to-date, is shared in a timely fashion, and is shared securely.
vii). Keep a record of your decision and the reasons for it – whether it is to share information or not. If you decide to share, then record what you have shared, with whom and for what purpose.
PREVENT – Supporting Vulnerable Individuals at Risk of Radicalisation

5.20.1 The Government's PREVENT strategy aims to stop people from being radicalised or from supporting terrorism. Service users and staff members may be exposed to exploitation by radicalisers who promote violence – Individuals may be susceptible to exploitation into violent extremism by radicalisers. Violent extremists often use persuasive rationale and charismatic individuals to attract people to their cause. The aim is to attract people to their reasoning, inspire new recruits and embed their extreme views and persuade vulnerable individuals of the legitimacy of their cause.

5.20.2 PREVENT is part of the Adult Safeguarding Policy because patients or staff who are suspected of being vulnerable to radicalisation are defined as victims of abuse and will then require a safeguarding referral. This should be considered alongside the PREVENT Policy that can be found on the Trusts intranet sites.

5.20.3 There are a number of factors that should not be considered in isolation but in conjunction with the particular circumstances of the individual: identity or personal crisis, particular personal; circumstances, unemployment or underemployment and criminality. All of these may contribute to alienation from UK values and a decision to cause harm to symbols of the community or the state.
5.20.4 It is the responsibility of all staff to know the Trust Process for PREVENT (on Trust intranet sites), who the site PREVENT Leads are and how and where to raise any concern.
Training Requirements
All staff within the Trust are required to attend mandatory safeguarding training in accordance with the MSE Training Needs Analysis and Competencies for HealthCare Staff.
All patient facing clinical staff and volunteers are required to complete Adult Safeguarding e-learning on appointment and update every 3 years.

Additional training should be undertaken according to the role and responsibilities according to the intercollegiate guidance. All staff must familiarise themselves with Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Guidelines which are available on the Trust Intranet sites and at http://www.safeguardingsouthend.co.uk/adults/index.html  and the Adult Safeguarding Roles and Competencies for Health Care Staff – Intercollegiate Guidance Document which can be found on Trust Intranet Sites.
Monitoring and Audit
A SET SAF Assurance Database is maintained regularly detailing all SET SAF information and additional information on other safeguarding concerns which may have not resulted in a SET SAF being raised.
A Quarterly Safeguarding Assurance Report and Annual Report are provided and presented to the MSE Safeguarding Committee in Common for Assurance.
The report outlines the following:
Governance and Assurance;
Adult Safeguarding activity raised by MEHT;
Categories of abuse, themes & trends;
Adult Safeguarding activity raised against MEHT;
Categories of abuse, themes & trends;
MCA/DoLS Activity;
Domestic Abuse activity;
Supervision;
Workforce allegations;
Domestic Homicide Reviews (DHR);
Serious Case Reviews (SCR);
Safeguarding Adult Developments;
MEHT Priorities Action and Development Plan;
The MSE Safeguarding Group has a 2 yearly audit plan to be able to assess and measure practice against best practice and process.
Approval and Implementation

This policy will be approved by the MSE Safeguarding Group which is the group with the authority to approve safeguarding policies. The policy will be forwarded to the Document Control Team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Safeguarding Group which is the group of the approved policy document when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets. This revised policy will be made available to staff on the Trust's intranet site and website.
All new staff will be made aware of the policy during staff induction training.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid & South Essex University Hospitals Group is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 4)

Appendix 1
Abuse Types and Possible Indicators ABUSE

Safeguarding means protecting an adult's right to live in safety, free from abuse and neglect. It is about people and organisations working together to prevent and stop both the risks and experience of abuse or neglect, while at the same time making sure that the adult's wellbeing is promoted including, where appropriate, having regard to their views, wishes, feelings and beliefs in deciding on any action.

Abuse can take place in any setting - these guidelines are applicable to all settings; an individual's private home, care home, hospital, day service, public transport, park, Police station or college. This list is endless.

It is therefore, also important to recognise that abuse can consist of a single or repeated act(s); that it can be intentional or unintentional or result from a lack of knowledge. Abuse can be an act of neglect or an omission or a failure to act. Abuse can cause temporary harm or exist over a period of time and can occur in any relationship. Abuse can be perpetrated by anyone, individually or as part of a group or organisation. Importantly, abuse can often constitute a crime.

Abuse is NOT an accident and nor is an accident abuse. For example, if someone who is usually able to drink independently is handed a cup of tea, which they then spill resulting in red marks to the top of their legs, then this would be an accident. Whereas, if a person who is known not to be able to drink independently with an adapted cup is handed a cup of tea in a standard cup and is left to try to drink it independently but subsequently spills it and sustains a scald then this may constitute negligence.
Patterns of abuse can vary and include:
Serial abusing in which the perpetrator seeks out and grooms individuals. Sexual abuse sometimes falls into this pattern as do some forms of financial abuse;
Long term abuse in the context of an ongoing family relationship such as domestic violence between spouses or generations or persistent psychological abuse; or
Opportunistic abuse such as theft occurring because money or jewellery has been left lying around.
Categories of abuse

This section considers the different types and patterns of abuse and neglect and the different circumstances in which they may take place. This is not intended to be an exhaustive list but an illustrative guide as to the sort of behaviour which could give rise to a safeguarding concern.
Physical abuse – The non-accidental infliction of physical force that results (or could result) in bodily injury, pain or impairment including; Assault, hitting, slapping, pushing, misuse of
medication, restraint or inappropriate physical sanctions, accumulation of minor accidents without seeking medical assistance.

Possible indicators of abuse include unexplained bruising, cowering or flinching, bruising consistent with being hit, unexplained burns, unexplained fractures, scalds especially with well-defined edges e.g. from emersion in water.

Domestic violence and abuse – Incident or pattern of incidents of controlling, coercive or threatening behaviour, violence or abuse by someone who is or has been an intimate partner or family member regardless of gender or sexuality. Domestic abuse is not just about partners but all family relationships. This includes: psychological, physical, sexual, financial, emotional abuse; so called ‘honour' based violence; Female Genital Mutilation; forced marriage. The age range for domestic abuse has been extended down to 16.

Many people think that domestic abuse is about intimate partners, but it is clear that other family members are included and that much safeguarding work that occurs at home is in fact concerned with domestic abuse. This confirms that domestic abuse approaches and legislation can be considered safeguarding responses in appropriate cases.
Within domestic abuse, controlling and coercive behaviour is now a criminal offence punishable by up to 5 years in prison (Serious Crime Act 2015, Section 76).
‘So-called honour based violence is a crime or incident, which has or may have been committed to protect or defend the honour of the family and/or community' – Forced Marriage Unit, Home Office.

All practitioners working with victims of forced marriage and violence in the name of honour need to be aware of the ‘one chance” rule. That is, they may only have one chance to speak to the potential victim and thus they may only have one chance to save a life. This means that all practitioners working within statutory agencies needs to be aware of their responsibilities and obligations when they come across these cases. If the victim is allowed to walk out of the door without support being offered, that one chance might be wasted.

Possible domestic abuse indicators include people being prevented from seeing family/friends, prevented from attending college/work/appointments, being followed or continuingly being asked where they are, accusations regarding other relationships unjustly, feeling scared of others, being threatened personally or threats against other family/friends, prevented from leaving the home, withholding finances, being forced to do something unwanted for their partner.

Sexual abuse – Direct or indirect involvement in sexual activity without consent. This could also be the inability to consent, pressured or induced to consent or take part. Could include: rape, indecent exposure, sexual harassment, inappropriate looking or touching, sexual teasing or innuendo, sexual photography, subjection to pornography or witnessing sexual acts, indecent exposure and sexual assault or sexual acts to which the adult has not consented or was pressured into consenting.

Indicators of sexual abuse include unexplained changes in behaviours, incontinence/bed- wetting, difficulty/discomfort in walking, excessive washing, sexually transmitted diseases, pregnancy, bruising/bleeding in genital or rectal area, deliberate self-harm, unexplained love bites.

Psychological abuse – Acts or behaviour which impinge on the emotional health of, or which causes distress or anguish to, individuals. This may also be present in other forms of abuse. Some examples include: emotional abuse, threats of harm or abandonment, deprivation of contact, humiliation, blaming, controlling, intimidation, coercion, harassment, verbal abuse, cyber bullying, isolation or unreasonable and unjustified withdrawal of services or supportive networks.

Possible indicators could be; disturbed sleep, anxiety, confusion, extreme submissiveness or dependency, sharp changes in behaviour in the presence of certain people, self-abusive behaviours, loss of confidence, loss of appetite.

Financial or material abuse – Unauthorised, fraudulent obtaining and improper use of funds, property or any resources of an adult at risk from abuse. Financial abuse is the main form of abuse by the Office of the Public Guardian both among adults and children at risk. Financial recorded abuse can occur in isolation, but as research has shown, where there are other forms of abuse, there is likely to be financial abuse occurring. Staff should be aware of this possibility. Most financial abuse could amount to theft or fraud and so would be a matter for the Police to investigate. It may also require attention and collaboration from a wider group of organisations, including shops and financial institutions such as banks.

Where the abuse is by someone who has the authority to manage an adult's money, the relevant body should be informed, for example, the Office of the Public Guardian for deputies and Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) in relation to appointees.

Examples including theft, fraud, internet scamming, coercion in relation to an adult's financial affairs or arrangements, including in connection with wills, property, inheritance or financial transactions, or the misuse or misappropriation of property, possessions or benefits. In practice possible signs include unexplained or sudden inability to pay bills, unexplained withdrawal of money from accounts, personal possessions going missing, contrast being known income and actual living conditions, unusual interest by friend/relative/neighbour in financial matters, pressure from next of kin for formal arrangements being set up.

Modern slavery – Encompasses slavery, human trafficking, forced labour and domestic servitude. Traffickers and slave masters use whatever means they have at their disposal to coerce, deceive and force individuals into a life of abuse, servitude and inhumane treatment.
Possible indicators include poor physical appearance, isolation, poor living conditions, few or no personal effects, restricted freedom of movement, unusual travel habits, reluctance to seek help.

There is a great potential for victims of modern slavery and human trafficking to be in the UK illegally. Therefore, to rule this possibility out, please contact the safeguarding team if you suspect your patient is or may be an illegal immigrant. Possible signs may be a patient with no NHS number, who does not speak English, cannot give a date of birth and/or does not have access to their passport.
Discriminatory abuse – Discriminatory abuse exists when values, beliefs or culture result in a misuse of power that denies mainstream opportunities to some groups or individuals.

Examples including forms of harassment, slurs or similar treatment; because of race, gender and gender identity, age, disability, sexual orientation or religion. In practice this may look like acts or comments motivated to harm and damage including inciting others to commit abusive acts, lack of effective communication provision e.g. interpretation, the adult being subjected to racist, sexist, ageist, gender based abuse, or abuse specifically about their disability.

Organisational abuse – Abuse occurs where the culture of the organisation (such as a care home or hospital) places emphasis on the running of the establishment and the needs of the staff above the needs and care of the person including neglect and poor care practice within an institution or specific care setting such as a hospital or care home, for example, or in relation to care provided in one's own home from domiciliary services. This may range from one off incidents to on-going ill-treatment. It can be through neglect or poor professional practice as a result of the structure, policies, processes and practices within an organisation.

Possible indicators include lack of care plans, contact with outside world not encouraged, no flexibility or lack of choice e.g. poor pain control, not getting medication on time which results in harm, time when to get up in a morning or go to bed or what to eat, routines are engineered for the benefit of staff, lack of personal effects, strong smell of urine, staff not visiting for allocated time due to pressure resulting in some tasks not being carried out fully, omission of visits, poor moving and handling practices.

Neglect and acts of omission – Ignoring or withholding physical or medical care needs which result in a situation or environment detrimental to individual(s). Ill-treatment and wilful neglect of a person who lacks capacity are now criminal offences under the Mental Capacity Act. Examples including ignoring medical, emotional or physical care needs, failure to provide access to appropriate health, care and support or educational services, the withholding of the necessities of life, such as medication, adequate nutrition and heating. This may be demonstrated by poor hygiene/cleanliness of the person who has been assessed as needing assistance, repeated infections, dehydration/weight loss/ malnutrition, repeated or unexplained falls or trips, withholding of assistance aids e.g. hearing aids or walking devices. Practitioners must respect the rights of the adult whilst seeking to ensure that their behaviour does not harm themselves or others. This means that there is an inherent right for the adult to take risks and a responsibility for the practitioner to help them identify and manage potential and actual risk to themselves and others. However, ignoring the risk or making the risk worse (intentionally or unintentionally) and placing an individual at harm is a safeguarding matter.
Ill-treatment and Wilful Neglect

The Mental Capacity Act created criminal offences of ill-treatment and wilful neglect in respect of people who lack the ability to make decisions. Ill treatment covers both deliberate acts of ill treatment and also those acts which are reckless and result in ill treatment. Wilful neglect requires a serious departure from the required standards of treatment and usually means that a person has deliberately failed to carry out an act they knew they were under a duty to perform.

Section 20 of the Criminal Justice and Courts Act 2015 makes it an offence for any individual who is caring for someone else to ill-treat or wilfully neglect that person. If found guilty, the maximum penalty can be a fine of £5000 and up to 5 years in prison (or both).
Self-neglect – This covers a wide range of behaviour neglecting to care for one's personal hygiene, health or surroundings and includes behaviour such as hoarding.

Self-neglect may or may not be a safeguarding issue, however agencies must assess concerns raised under their statutory duties; having consideration for an individual's right to choose their lifestyle, balanced with their mental health or capacity to understand the consequences of their actions.
Once identified as a situation that cannot be managed through regular case management, high risk or self-neglect situations will be managed through the safeguarding process.

Self-neglect is characterised as the behaviour of a person that threatens his/her own health or safety. Self-neglect generally manifests itself as a refusal or failure to provide himself/herself with adequate food, water, clothing, shelter, personal hygiene, medication (when indicated), and safety precautions.

The definition of self-neglect excludes a situation in which a mentally competent person, who understands the consequences of his/her decisions, makes a conscious and voluntary decision to engage in acts that threaten his/her health or safety as a matter of personal choice. Signs and symptoms of self-neglect include but are not limited to: dehydration, malnutrition, untreated or improperly attended medical conditions, and poor personal hygiene; hazardous or unsafe living conditions/arrangements (e.g. improper wiring, no indoor plumbing, no heat, no running water); unsanitary or unclean living quarters (e.g. animal/insect infestation, no functioning toilet, faecal/urine smell); inappropriate and/or inadequate clothing, lack of the necessary medical aids (e.g. glasses, hearing aids, dentures, walking aids); grossly inadequate housing or homelessness.
(SET Safeguarding Adult Guidance, April 2019)
